 I find this argument interesting but not very well thought out:
 
 “which should take precedence: The Constitution's First or Second Amendment? "Based on America's history, the Founders' answer to that question clearly lies in the Bill of Rights' deliberate sequencing.”
 
 If sequencing is the indicator of which right is more important—that the numbering is important and that the one which precedes is more important than the one which follows, then is the author prepared to accept the founders felt the RKBA was more important than, say, the right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure? Or the right to remain silent? Or the right to trial by jury? I’m not sure the author thought that argument through to its logical conclusion. 
 
 But in specific answer to the article let me say this. I oppose anyone who chooses to use intimidation as a method of deterring others from exercising their rights, be it free speech, the RKBA, or any other right protected by my Constitution. 
 
 “Yes, the gun has been transformed from a sport and self-defense device into a tool of mass bullying.”
 
 The gun has done nothing—and should not be blamed for the hand which improperly wields it. Every right carries with it the responsibility to exercise it properly. Incitement to riot is a crime whether one uses words, a firearm, or both to accomplish that illegitimate end—and neither the 1st. nor the 2nd. Amendment will protect such conduct.
 
 Our system of justice is based upon holding the guilty accountable for their actions. It is a fundamental principle of my government that we do not blame or punish the innocent for the crimes of the guilty, and neither do we blame the right for those who abuse the freedom it guarantees. No one blames the 1st. Amendment for the crimes committed by a few protestors at the latest G8 summit. No one seriously argues that we must limit free speech or assembly because a handful or protestors abused these rights. Neither should we seek to blame the 2nd. Amendment for the few who abuse that right by threatening or intimidating others. 
 
 If someone goes to a political gathering and brandishes a firearm in an attempt to intimidate others, then that person has committed a crime. He deserves no greater freedom from prosecution and punishment than the person who suggests the freedom to peaceably assemble and petition the government for a redress of his grievances grants him the right to throw a trash can through a store window. In both instances the person has gone far beyond the conduct protected by his “right”—and each person deserves to be punished for his actions.
 
 But it is only when guns are involved that we have persons using the misdeeds of the few to mount an attack on the Constitution for the freedoms it guarantees—treating an amendment like it is the red-headed step child of the Constitution which somehow deserves blame for conduct it neither sanctions nor endorses. 
 
 The article clearly seeks to set the 1st and 2nd. Amendments in opposition to one another, and it encourages the reader to take sides. I reject this simplistic either/or attempt to set the Constitution at odds with itself. I choose to protect the rights protected by both amendments—and I have no problem prosecuting those who infringe upon the free exercise of any right. I will not accept the invitation to pick and choose which portions of the Constitution are really worth defending. 
 
 (And I find it ironic that Mao has suddenly become the flavor of the month for those looking for a political quotation. Who would have suspected that so many new-left political philosophers had a copy of the little red book....) 
 
 ---
 
 Foolish liberals who are trying to read the Second Amendment out of the Constitution by claiming it’s not an individual right or that it's too much of a safety hazard don't see the danger of the big picture. They're courting disaster by encouraging others to use the same means to eliminate portions of the Constitution they don't like. Alan Dershowitz, quoted in David T. Hardy, The Conceptual Foundations of Anglo-American Jurisprudence in Religion and Reason, 62 Tenn L. Rev. 759 (1995).
 
 The great ideals of liberty and equality are preserved against the assaults of opportunism, the expediency of the passing hour, the erosion of small encroachments, the scorn and derision of those who have no patience with general principles, by enshrining them in constitutions, and consecrating to the task of their protection a body of defenders. Justice Benjamin Cardozo, The Nature of the Judicial Process, Lecture II, 1921.
 
 Experience should teach us to be most on our guard to protect liberty when the Government's purposes are beneficent. Men born to freedom are naturally alert to repel invasion of their liberty by evil-minded rulers. The greatest dangers to liberty lurk in insidious encroachment by men of zeal, well-meaning but without understanding. Olmstead v. United States, 277 U.S. 438, 485 (1928) Justice Brandeis, dissenting.

Not sure I follow what you are arguing, Doc. But I wonder if it was just the speech alone would the article have been written, or was it just because guns were present.
 
 It is not a crime to peaceably assemble. It is not a crime to do so while wearing a firearm. It is not a crime to quote Thomas Jefferson, no matter what others think of the wisdom of the quote. It is a crime, for example, to disrupt a meeting of a government body. See the following statute from my state:
 
 Willfully or being intoxicated, whether willfully or not, and whether such intoxication results from self-administered alcohol or other drug of whatever nature, disrupts any funeral, memorial service, or meeting of the governing body of any political subdivision of this Commonwealth or a division or agency thereof, or of any school, literary society or place of religious worship, if the disruption (i) prevents or interferes with the orderly conduct of the funeral, memorial service, or meeting or (ii) has a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person or persons at whom, individually, the disruption is directed. Virginia Code § 18.2-415
 
 Enforcement of this statute does not infringe upon the 1st amendment right to peaceably assemble and petition the government for a redress of grievances. 
 
 It is a crime in my state to "brandish" a firearm:
 
 It shall be unlawful for any person to point, hold or brandish any firearm or any air or gas operated weapon or any object similar in appearance, whether capable of being fired or not, in such manner as to reasonably induce fear in the mind of another or hold a firearm or any air or gas operated weapon in a public place in such a manner as to reasonably induce fear in the mind of another of being shot or injured. Virginia Code § 18.2-282 
 
 Enforcement of this statute does not violate the 2nd. Amendment RKBA (assuming incorporation, which SCOTUS will decide this coming year). Wearing a firearm on your hip or slung over your shoulder does not violate this statute. So we need to know what actions the author of the article refers to with the comment "the weapons-brandishing displays are 'intended to intimidate or coerce a civilian population.' It sounds like the author wishes to use fear as a weapon to unconstitutionally restrict the RKBA.
 
 If someone wears a gun in a holster and spouts off about watering the tree of liberty, then I might disagree with them and even think they are being foolish, but no crime is committed-and neither I nor anyone else is justified in denying someone a nonviolent exercise of their rights merely because we don't like the right or disagree with the content of their speech. If, on the other hand, they say it's time to start watering the tree, pull out their gun, and waive it around, then they deserve to be prosecuted for brandishing a firearm. In that case neither their right of free speech nor their RKBA will prevent the prosecution, because neither right was intended to protect such conduct. 
 
 The point I wanted to make was the article was less about seeking to hold someone accountable for their actions and more about using the example of a few as an excuse to mount an attack on a civil liberty.
